author: Agency Staff
title: NUM to call strike in coal sector | Labour
text:
Picture: SUNDAY TIMES Related articles Mines crisis pact unravels as NUM cries foul Under-pressure coal mines up wage offer to unions Coal workers’ wage dispute due for conciliation In this article Companies and organisations: National Union of Mineworkers THE National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) said on Wednesday it would give coal companies a 48-hour strike notice after wage talks collapsed.
"We have the certificate to strike and will give the companies 48-hour notice later," Peter Bailey, NUM’s chief negotiator in the coal sector, told Reuters.
NUM had been seeking wage hikes of up to 50% at one point but had scaled back and Mr Bailey said its latest demand for its lowest-paid members was for increases of R1,000 a month, which he said amounted to about 13%. A spokeswoman for the Chamber of Mines, which represents Glencore, Anglo American Coal and Exxaro, said the coal producers had raised their offer to wage hikes of up to 8.5% for the lowest-paid workers, from 8% previously.
Inflation is currently running at 4.6%. About 30,000 workers could take part in the strike by the NUM. Two smaller unions which represent mostly skilled workers and supervisors accepted the coal offers last week.
Like other mining sectors, coal has been hard hit by sliding commodity prices in the face of slowing Chinese growth, while power and labour costs in SA have been rising sharply in recent years.
But SA’s mine workers have been growing increasingly militant amid perceptions that wages for the mostly black labour force remain too low two decades after the end of apartheid rule.
Eskom said it only had enough coal to last up to a month.
“Most of our power stations have a 30 day supply of coal, if the strike goes beyond that period, we will have to make another plan,” Eskom’s spokesman Khulu Phasiwe told Reuters.
One option would be to truck coal directly from the mines to power stations.
Reuters
